vulnerability_information: **Summary** Invitation page contains iframes that points to https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/ and https://a4l.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/. A *GET* request to these endpoints executes a script that points to `https://bat.bing.com/bat.js`. The corresponding request to bing contains the invitation tokens. **Description** While checking the source code of an team invitation page (https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc), I found two iframe links - `https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc` and `https://a4l.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc` where `8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc`is the invitation token. {F250542} To find out more about these endpoints,i issued a simple GET requests to these urls. GET requests to these endpoints returned a page that contains a script that points to - `https://bat.bing.com/bat.js`. The response of the GET request to https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc looks as follows: ``` ``` As we can see the page calls a script at `https://bat.bing.com/bat.js` and the script is executed. The script fires a corresponding request to bat.bing.com that contains the invitation token. It looks as follows: ``` https://bat.bing.com/action/0?ti=5295042&Ver=2&mid=ab8e7bd3-541b-59ea-0551-7041b2ede6e3&evt=pageLoad&sid=bbebc657-0<=127&pi=1001431019&lg=en-US&sw=1366&sh=768&sc=24&p=https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc&r=&msclkid=N&rn=664767 ``` The `p` parameter contains the entire url along with the invitation token - `p=https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc` where `8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc`is the invitation token. Thus the invitation token is sent to bat.bing.com as a part of the request. ## Impact 1. Leaking member invitation tokens can reveal pretty much everything about a program. 1. Private programs could be adversely affected by leaking private invitation tokens.
title: Invitation token leaks to https://bat.bing.com

activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for reporting @zuriel, we're looking into this and will get back to you shortly.

Kind regards,
@asuka

activities.message: Hi @zuriel - thanks for your reporting. However, I have some trouble reproducing your report. When I go to the page, both authenticated and unauthenticated, I don't see any iframes. Perhaps this is a browser extension that does this. Can you help me reproduce the bug? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @zuriel - thanks for your reporting. However, I have some trouble reproducing your report. When I go to the page, both authenticated and unauthenticated, I don't see any iframes. Perhaps this is a browser extension that does this. Can you help me reproduce the bug? Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @jobert 

{F250542}

As you can see the screenshot I had attached, this is from the latest firefox quantum version 57.0.3.

Well you could try these steps:

 1. Visit https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc
 2. Click developer options and select network tab.
 
I think you are probably looking at the inspector tab. 

Actually there is no much significance to the iframe here. I just spotted the urls that was leaking the tokens in the iframes.  

You could simply visit any of these urls:

+ https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc
+ https://a4l.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc

1. A simple GET request to any of these above  links should be enough. 
2. Capture the traffic following the GET request, 
3. Meanwhile you can inspect the source of above pages and find the script that points to bat.bing.com/bat.js
4. A request to https://bat.bing.com should be recorded, that contains the above invitation tokens.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jobert

As you can see the screenshot I had attached, this is from the latest firefox quantum version 57.0.3.

Well you could try these steps:

  1. Visit https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc
  2. Click developer options and select network tab.

I think you are probably looking at the inspector tab.

Actually there is no much significance to the iframe here. I just spotted the urls that was leaking the tokens in the iframes.

You could simply visit any of these urls:

  • https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc
  • https://a4l.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc
  1. A simple GET request to any of these above links should be enough.
  2. Capture the traffic following the GET request,
  3. Meanwhile you can inspect the source of above pages and find the script that points to bat.bing.com/bat.js
  4. A request to https://bat.bing.com should be recorded, that contains the above invitation tokens.

activities.message: My bad, I now see them. We'll get this fixed. Thanks for your follow up!
activities.markdown_message: My bad, I now see them. We'll get this fixed. Thanks for your follow up!

@jobert

IMPACT

  1. The invitation token link contains sensitive information like the invitee's email address.

  2. So we are indirectly disclosing the email address of a hackerone user by leaking invitation tokens. 

{
    "token": "8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc",
    "type": "Invitations::TeamMember",
    "auth_option": "use-existing-account",
    "email": "dedgesw@mailinator.com",
    "status": "never",
    "expires_at": null,
    "invited_by": {
        "username": "zuriel",
        "profile_picture": "https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/production/000/217/627/54b42b13cf3eb23bb53437284bf20b09c4281e03_emailmedium.jpg?1510843440",
        "url": "https://hackerone.com/zuriel"
    },
    "team": {
        "name": "zurieltest",
        "handle": "zurieltest",
        "state": "sandboxed",
        "profile_picture": "https://profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com/production/000/025/196/f11ba319087149ad4d02df4d146dc290a321904c_emailmedium.png?1514530478",
        "url": "https://hackerone.com/zurieltest",
        "team_members": [{
            "username": "secret_api_token_identifier"
        }, {
            "username": "zuriel"
        }, {
            "username": "demo-member"
        }]
    }
}

As we can see the email address of the invitee team member is returned if we visit the invitation link - https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc

Hence, Anyone with invitation link can also see the email id of the new team member.

I request you to please reconsider the severity!

Thanks

activities.message: Hi @zuriel - this would only be a problem for users that are not known in our database. When it's a known user, other users can't view the invitation. Since it could disclosed other people their email addresses, we're awarding our minimum bounty here. Thanks again and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @zuriel - this would only be a problem for users that are not known in our database. When it's a known user, other users can't view the invitation. Since it could disclosed other people their email addresses, we're awarding our minimum bounty here. Thanks again and happy hacking!

activities.message:
**Update**

Now when we click on https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc, following page:

{F251795}

The corresponding json response is as follows:

```
{
  "token": "8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc",
  "type": "Invitations::TeamMember",
  "auth_option": "has-no-access",
  "email": "dedgesw@mailinator.com",
  "status": "never",
  "expires_at": null,
  "recipient": {
    "username": "dedgesw",
    "profile_picture": "https:\/\/profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com\/production\/000\/228\/203\/d47a48354413d3173f4d8a758f1592a2db33f94c_emaillarge.jpg?1514920190",
    "url": "https:\/\/hackerone.com\/dedgesw"
  }
}
```

Now the `auth-option` is changed to `has-no-access`. - Fixed

**But** , now the response also contains **username** of the recipient. Along with the **email-id** of the user. 

###IMPACT 

1. This  fix is brought about to  prevent misuse of invitation tokens even if an email was hacked. And only the genuine recipient would be able to access it.
1. But the context of the current report does not involve a email hack. 
1. Now, the _username and email-id_ of users are both disclosed in the response.
activities.markdown_message:
Update

Now when we click on https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc, following page:

The corresponding json response is as follows:

{
  "token": "8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc",
  "type": "Invitations::TeamMember",
  "auth_option": "has-no-access",
  "email": "dedgesw@mailinator.com",
  "status": "never",
  "expires_at": null,
  "recipient": {
    "username": "dedgesw",
    "profile_picture": "https:\/\/profile-photos.hackerone-user-content.com\/production\/000\/228\/203\/d47a48354413d3173f4d8a758f1592a2db33f94c_emaillarge.jpg?1514920190",
    "url": "https:\/\/hackerone.com\/dedgesw"
  }
}

Now the auth-option is changed to has-no-access. - Fixed

But , now the response also contains username of the recipient. Along with the email-id of the user.

IMPACT

  1. This fix is brought about to prevent misuse of invitation tokens even if an email was hacked. And only the genuine recipient would be able to access it.
  2. But the context of the current report does not involve a email hack.
  3. Now, the username and email-id of users are both disclosed in the response.

activities.message:
Hi @jobert,

Earlier, the identity of the recipient on an invitation page was unknown. But now the presence of **username** discloses the recipient identity. Already mentioned [above](https://hackerone.com/reports/301526#activity-2267241)

Should this be submitted as a new report?

activities.message: That's intentional behavior. Before disclosing it, would you mind revoking the invitation? Thanks again, much appreciated!
activities.markdown_message: That's intentional behavior. Before disclosing it, would you mind revoking the invitation? Thanks again, much appreciated!

activities.message:
Invitation has been revoked. Thank you very much for the bounty! 

But what about the presence of **username** and **email-id** on the invitation page? If the invitation token is leaked in a way similar to the scenario as of this report, the username and email-id would be leaked. 

Could you confirm whether this  can be tolerated before we disclose this?
activities.markdown_message:
Invitation has been revoked. Thank you very much for the bounty!

But what about the presence of username and email-id on the invitation page? If the invitation token is leaked in a way similar to the scenario as of this report, the username and email-id would be leaked.

Could you confirm whether this can be tolerated before we disclose this?

activities.message: I believe that if someone has access to the token, which can only be obtained when someone has access to the user's email inbox, it is fine to show these attributes. We might change this in the future, but up until then, this is fine. Thanks for asking!
activities.markdown_message: I believe that if someone has access to the token, which can only be obtained when someone has access to the user's email inbox, it is fine to show these attributes. We might change this in the future, but up until then, this is fine. Thanks for asking!

activities.message: Thanks for the confirmation @jobert. Let us disclose this now!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the confirmation @jobert. Let us disclose this now!

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary

Invitation page contains iframes that points to https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/<invitation token> and https://a4l.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/<invitation token>. A GET request to these endpoints executes a script that points to https://bat.bing.com/bat.js. The corresponding request to bing contains the invitation tokens.

Description

While checking the source code of an team invitation page (https://hackerone.com/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc), I found two iframe links - https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc and https://a4l.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc where 8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbcis the invitation token.

To find out more about these endpoints,i issued a simple GET requests to these urls. GET requests to these endpoints returned a page that contains a script that points to - https://bat.bing.com/bat.js.

The response of the GET request to https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc looks as follows: 

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head></head>
  <body style="background-color: transparent">
    <script>
      (function(w,d,t,r,u){var f,n,i;w[u]=w[u]||[],f=function(){var o={ti:"5295042"};o.q=w[u],w[u]=new UET(o),w[u].push("pageLoad")},n=d.createElement(t),n.src=r,n.async=1,n.onload=n.onreadystatechange=function(){var s=this.readyState;s&&s!=="loaded"&&s!=="complete"||(f(),n.onload=n.onreadystatechange=null)},i=d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0],i.parentNode.insertBefore(n,i)})(window,document,"script","https://bat.bing.com/bat.js","uetq");
    </script>
    <noscript>
      <img src="//bat.bing.com/action/0?ti=5295042&Ver=2" height="0" width="0" style="display:none; visibility: hidden;" />
    </noscript>
  </body>
</html>

As we can see the page calls a script at https://bat.bing.com/bat.js and the script is executed.

The script fires a corresponding request to bat.bing.com that contains the invitation token. It looks as follows:

https://bat.bing.com/action/0?ti=5295042&Ver=2&mid=ab8e7bd3-541b-59ea-0551-7041b2ede6e3&evt=pageLoad&sid=bbebc657-0&lt=127&pi=1001431019&lg=en-US&sw=1366&sh=768&sc=24&p=https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc&r=&msclkid=N&rn=664767

The p parameter contains the entire url along with the invitation token - p=https://b5s.hackerone-ext-content.com/#!/invitations/8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbc where 8e44119f60be8670d1e3f99a01359cbcis the invitation token.

Thus the invitation token is sent to bat.bing.com as a part of the request.

Impact

  1. Leaking member invitation tokens can reveal pretty much everything about a program.
  2. Private programs could be adversely affected by leaking private invitation tokens.

profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.
profile.name: HackerOne
